post.body:
>Changing World, Changing Mozilla
>Mitchell Baker August 11, 2020

>This is a time of change for the internet and for Mozilla. From combatting a lethal virus and battling systemic racism to protecting individual privacy — one thing is clear: an open and accessible internet is essential to the fight.

>Today we announced a significant restructuring of Mozilla Corporation. This will strengthen our ability to build and invest in products and services that will give people alternatives to conventional Big Tech. Sadly, the changes also include a significant reduction in our workforce by approximately 250 people.
>https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/08/11/changing-world-changing-mozilla/
IT'S OVER
post.body_html:
Changing World, Changing Mozilla Mitchell Baker August 11, 2020

This is a time of change for the internet and for Mozilla. From combatting a lethal virus and battling systemic racism to protecting individual privacy — one thing is clear: an open and accessible internet is essential to the fight.

Today we announced a significant restructuring of Mozilla Corporation. This will strengthen our ability to build and invest in products and services that will give people alternatives to conventional Big Tech. Sadly, the changes also include a significant reduction in our workforce by approximately 250 people. https://blog.mozilla.org/blog/2020/08/11/changing-world-changing-mozilla/ IT'S OVER
post.title: Its over

post.body:
1. Limitation of posting if you're downvoted: It's really retarded, it kills free speech. That shouldn't exist in very frist place.

2. "Anti-Evil" operations: I guess I don't have to explain why

3. Awards: Ok you need money I get it but it's really retarded when a post gets downvoted to oblivion but has 494838303039 awards. For example, Shit Arts posted some BS about microtranscation in BF2 and it got +600K downvote but got so much gold and platin award that account still has Reddit Premium to this day

body: Adding the ability to disable downvotes per-guild would seriously promote the development of echo-chambers. If we're going to remove downvotes (which we shouldn't), we should do it globally.
body_html: Adding the ability to disable downvotes per-guild would seriously promote the development of echo-chambers. If we're going to remove downvotes (which we shouldn't), we should do it globally.

post.body:
Guildmaster of +Rimworld made multiple posts complaining about being downvoted, calling for Ruqqus to remove downvotes, saying he wants see usernames so he can ban people who downvote him, asking people to upvote him, etc.

https://ruqqus.com/post/264i/remove-votes-from-replies-to-replies

https://ruqqus.com/post/2637/you-should-be-able-to-see

As you might expect he received even more downvotes from people exercising their right to disagree resulting in a knee-jerk kicking of all posts in his guild, including those not made by him.

His rules have been update to include the text:

*Awww, were you looking to downvote everything here, retard? Tough luck.*

A shinning example of an intelligent guildmaster properly using his powers for the good of his guild members
post.body_html:
Guildmaster of +Rimworld made multiple posts complaining about being downvoted, calling for Ruqqus to remove downvotes, saying he wants see usernames so he can ban people who downvote him, asking people to upvote him, etc.

https://ruqqus.com/post/264i/remove-votes-from-replies-to-replies

https://ruqqus.com/post/2637/you-should-be-able-to-see

As you might expect he received even more downvotes from people exercising their right to disagree resulting in a knee-jerk kicking of all posts in his guild, including those not made by him.

His rules have been update to include the text:

Awww, were you looking to downvote everything here, retard? Tough luck.

A shinning example of an intelligent guildmaster properly using his powers for the good of his guild members
post.title: Power-Tripping Guildmaster Kicks All Posts After Downvote Tantrum

post.title: Rescued fox kit, sleeping in someone's arms

body:
Telegram:
- [Hourly fops](https://t.me/HourlyFops) (hourly fox images)
- [Fennec friends](https://t.me/FennecFriends)
- [Рыжее Хвостейшество](https://t.me/redtaily) (fox images/occassional art)
- [foxposting](https://t.me/foxposting) (semi-active these days)

There's also [bestioline](https://t.me/bestioline) (Italian animal/meme channel), which *occassionally* posts a fox, but I don't follow it because they also forward stuff from another Italian meme channel which I don't enjoy.

Twitter:
- [coolfoxaccount](https://twitter.com/CoolFoxAccount)
- [hourlyFox](https://twitter.com/hourlyFox)

Note: If you follow these accounts, Twitter may start putting furries in your "who to follow" lists.

Youtube:
- [Juniper Foxx](https://www.youtube.com/c/JuniperFox/videos) (also exists on Instagram but I don't go there)
- [Alice the fox](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCiEFbQHfI-iiez0NBr6ZV1g) (entirely russian, including titles, descriptions, her owner's voice and literally all comments)
- [SaveAFox](https://www.youtube.com/c/SaveAFox)

If you subscribe to these, Youtube will start recommending fox videos from a variety of sources, most of which come from channels not at all focused on foxes.

Other:
- https://foxrudor.de/ (random fox image every refresh)
- http://fox-info.net/ (Japanese blog, no idea what they're saying but there are plenty of pics) (edit: do not use HTTPS when visiting as that's broken on their end)
- [Raddle/f/foxes](https://raddle.me/f/foxes) (raddle is an anarchist/communist Reddit alternative, /f/foxes is also pretty dead but it may or may not get resurrected at some point.)
- I've also found *a few* good fox images on 4chan, mostly in /wg/, but I haven't looked there very much.

Occassionally I discover new sources by following forwarded/retweeted/etc items from known sources. When that happens I usually go through the last few dozen pages of their existing content and save some of it on my phone, posting some of it when I feel like it.

If you're interested, these also exist:
- [Telegram/Otter gang](https://t.me/ottergang)
- [Telegram/Otters](https://t.me/cuteotters)
- [Telegram/Pander paradise](https://t.me/pander_paradise) (red pandas)
- [Twitter/Red Panda Every Hour](https://twitter.com/redpandaeveryhr)
- [Twitter/Raccoon Every Hour](https://twitter.com/raccooneveryhr)
- [Twitter/Possum Every Hour](https://twitter.com/PossumEveryHour)
- [Twitter/BatEveryHour](https://twitter.com/BatEveryHour)
- [Twitter/Gators Daily](https://twitter.com/GatorsDaily)
- [Twitter/Quokka Every Hour](https://twitter.com/quokkaeveryhour) (semi-active)
- [Twitter/Cow of the Day](https://twitter.com/CowoftheDay1)
- [Twitter/Capybaras](https://twitter.com/CapybaraCountry) (also posts memes, and retweets non-capybara related promotions)

There's probably a bunch of other specific animal Twitter pages if you're willing to look for them, I suggest following the rabbit hole of related accounts instead of searching.
body_html:
Telegram:

  • Hourly fops (hourly fox images)
  • Fennec friends
  • Рыжее Хвостейшество (fox images/occassional art)
  • foxposting (semi-active these days)

There's also bestioline (Italian animal/meme channel), which occassionally posts a fox, but I don't follow it because they also forward stuff from another Italian meme channel which I don't enjoy.

Twitter:

  • coolfoxaccount
  • hourlyFox

Note: If you follow these accounts, Twitter may start putting furries in your "who to follow" lists.

Youtube:

  • Juniper Foxx (also exists on Instagram but I don't go there)
  • Alice the fox (entirely russian, including titles, descriptions, her owner's voice and literally all comments)
  • SaveAFox

If you subscribe to these, Youtube will start recommending fox videos from a variety of sources, most of which come from channels not at all focused on foxes.

Other:

  • https://foxrudor.de/ (random fox image every refresh)
  • http://fox-info.net/ (Japanese blog, no idea what they're saying but there are plenty of pics) (edit: do not use HTTPS when visiting as that's broken on their end)
  • Raddle/f/foxes (raddle is an anarchist/communist Reddit alternative, /f/foxes is also pretty dead but it may or may not get resurrected at some point.)
  • I've also found a few good fox images on 4chan, mostly in /wg/, but I haven't looked there very much.

Occassionally I discover new sources by following forwarded/retweeted/etc items from known sources. When that happens I usually go through the last few dozen pages of their existing content and save some of it on my phone, posting some of it when I feel like it.

If you're interested, these also exist:

  • Telegram/Otter gang
  • Telegram/Otters
  • Telegram/Pander paradise (red pandas)
  • Twitter/Red Panda Every Hour
  • Twitter/Raccoon Every Hour
  • Twitter/Possum Every Hour
  • Twitter/BatEveryHour
  • Twitter/Gators Daily
  • Twitter/Quokka Every Hour (semi-active)
  • Twitter/Cow of the Day
  • Twitter/Capybaras (also posts memes, and retweets non-capybara related promotions)

There's probably a bunch of other specific animal Twitter pages if you're willing to look for them, I suggest following the rabbit hole of related accounts instead of searching.

parent.body: I see you frequently post a lot of other images and videos too. What feeds/websites are you subscribed to in general, ie where do you *usually* find all those fox pictures? Are they all just saved up over the years like this one, or are there specific places you know of to look? A lot of posters (yourself included) find a bunch of new fox pics/gifs in abundance, so I've always wondered where they're getting them from. It takes me way too much effort to find even one or two new good ones because I don't know of any good sources, and I've had to resort to reposting old stuff quite a lot when the guild/sub was in need of more content.

body:
I find Google to be superior to many sites' built-in search tools. You can search within a specific site by including "site:twitter.com" (or "site:twitter.com/username", which searches a specific person's tweets). This also lets you use Google's search query syntax, and allows you to exclude Fox News:

> fox -news site:twitter.com

Not perfect, you may have to exclude a few more terms like "trump" and "sports". DuckDuckGo supports the same syntax.

Finally, searching may not be the way to go. Once you find a good page, Twitter will show you related pages, which lets you go down the rabbit hole in a recursive-algorithm-style search.
body_html:
I find Google to be superior to many sites' built-in search tools. You can search within a specific site by including "site:twitter.com" (or "site:twitter.com/username", which searches a specific person's tweets). This also lets you use Google's search query syntax, and allows you to exclude Fox News:

fox -news site:twitter.com

Not perfect, you may have to exclude a few more terms like "trump" and "sports". DuckDuckGo supports the same syntax.

Finally, searching may not be the way to go. Once you find a good page, Twitter will show you related pages, which lets you go down the rabbit hole in a recursive-algorithm-style search.

body:
> They know nearly every single language super well.

Not me. I am good at C# and speak only a little bit of some other languages. I don't even bother writing in anything else because I don't need to, and because I can't get anything done nearly as fast (which is BECAUSE I don't bother getting experience in other languages).

I noticed that the profiles you linked are not all polyglots, GingkathFox and I write primarily one language. jakemayeux and Dog2puppy, who have public projects in multiple languages, don't have nearly as much (public) activity as we do.

And like headzoo said, C++ is a difficult language. C# and JS are much more high-level and allow you to get stuff done faster, but are less powerful and generally slower than C++.
body_html:
They know nearly every single language super well.

Not me. I am good at C# and speak only a little bit of some other languages. I don't even bother writing in anything else because I don't need to, and because I can't get anything done nearly as fast (which is BECAUSE I don't bother getting experience in other languages).

I noticed that the profiles you linked are not all polyglots, GingkathFox and I write primarily one language. jakemayeux and Dog2puppy, who have public projects in multiple languages, don't have nearly as much (public) activity as we do.

And like headzoo said, C++ is a difficult language. C# and JS are much more high-level and allow you to get stuff done faster, but are less powerful and generally slower than C++.

guild.name: Programming

parent.body:
> Have you tried other languages?

Yes, but I know them just enough to make changes in other projects. Trying to make stuff on my own with them ups the time it takes to create the smallest things from days to weeks. Unlike the other devs who seem to know every single language very well and can do pretty much anything in a few days max.

> C/C++ have specific usages which aren't exactly... fun.

My project is the most fun one of all! The other devs' projects are just stuff they made out of boredom for no reason, or for their convenience. While they mostly took mere hours to complete, anything I make like that will take days and probably never even work at all, let alone become polished apps. And even my super exciting projects are always half baked and could never feasibly be released, and I'm only capable of building things for my specific platform (so no mobile or raspberry pi apps or anything).

> There's some C# in there but most of those accounts are using javascript, css, html, php, etc.

Exactly, they know nearly every single language super well. I only know 3, and even those probably only as much as those devs know their non-main languages! Also, C# is the majority of it. They also seem to somehow know every single feature of every language, as well as every library on the planet and everything about them.

> I'm not sure what kind of projects you've been building but being a webdev can be a lot of fun because you can create things that will be instantly seen and used by thousands of people just by sharing a link to your site/app.

That's not really how it works. Does every reddit post get popular? None of these projects are getting much attention, and it's been clearly stated that they're just casually making them out of boredom or for convenience.

> What kind of open source projects do you contribute to?

Besides my own, Ruqqus. Why do you ask?
parent.body_html:
Have you tried other languages?

Yes, but I know them just enough to make changes in other projects. Trying to make stuff on my own with them ups the time it takes to create the smallest things from days to weeks. Unlike the other devs who seem to know every single language very well and can do pretty much anything in a few days max.

C/C++ have specific usages which aren't exactly... fun.

My project is the most fun one of all! The other devs' projects are just stuff they made out of boredom for no reason, or for their convenience. While they mostly took mere hours to complete, anything I make like that will take days and probably never even work at all, let alone become polished apps. And even my super exciting projects are always half baked and could never feasibly be released, and I'm only capable of building things for my specific platform (so no mobile or raspberry pi apps or anything).

There's some C# in there but most of those accounts are using javascript, css, html, php, etc.

Exactly, they know nearly every single language super well. I only know 3, and even those probably only as much as those devs know their non-main languages! Also, C# is the majority of it. They also seem to somehow know every single feature of every language, as well as every library on the planet and everything about them.

I'm not sure what kind of projects you've been building but being a webdev can be a lot of fun because you can create things that will be instantly seen and used by thousands of people just by sharing a link to your site/app.

That's not really how it works. Does every reddit post get popular? None of these projects are getting much attention, and it's been clearly stated that they're just casually making them out of boredom or for convenience.

What kind of open source projects do you contribute to?

Besides my own, Ruqqus. Why do you ask?

post.body:
This *is* a repost but I posted the last one last night, and I wanted to hit the opposite timezones as well to get a wide range of answers. So if you already saw this post, I apologize, and you can ignore it.

---

I started my first programming about 8 years ago in Java. It didn't get serious until about 4 years ago however, and a year after that I started C and C++.

I find it fun and enjoyable building things. Needless to say though, as much as I like it and do it a lot, I fucking suck, like I do at pretty much everything in life.

All the people I've met in programming channels on this site, discord, github, etc could finish even my biggest projects, which took me weeks, in a day or even mere hours, by putting in about half as much effort. Most people can finish several semi-professional projects in a month, albeit small, and each one takes them only a few hours to make, and a few days to *finish*, entirely by themselves. They can also take a few months to build very complex applications, by themselves. I have *never* made anything even remotely releasable in my whole life, just a bunch of shit that only I can use, and it always has a ton of problems that I can never figure out and every one of my solutions is half-baked. In fact, most of my intended projects never even end up being able to execute at all, let alone become mature. I run into so many problems that I have probably never written more than 100 lines in a day, even though most people can do thousands. Everything I do is just out of boredom too, I can't even write a small program that's actually useful in any way. In a nutshell, "hello world" is still the only thing I can make that's fully in working order.

Most devs also seem to know just about every single language in existence, no sweat. Not just a "I kinda know how to use it" deal, an actual rich understanding of all of them, knowing all the nooks and crannies of each one. Me? I know Java, C, and C++. And even those I don't have a particularly good understanding of, just enough to get things done. I have to google even very basic things that even people who don't use those as their main language would know about. I am also completely unable to make anything for platforms other than the one I'm currently using. No raspberry pi, no android, no web apps, nothing. I can't use CMake or anything either, because I'm still too busy figuring out everything else after so many years.

Wtf is wrong with me? Why am I so bad?

---

Some people in my last post weren't believing me, so here is an example of some devs who frequently make simple, small projects that should be trivial to complete. These are the things I cannot do, even though they're so small and simple. In fact I can not even come close, despite how easy it should be to make such small apps. Most of these devs also have one or two large complex projects, made all by themselves. Note that these are *not* top users I saw on github, they're just the people I know from the Ruqqus dev chats!

https://ruqqus.com/post/244k/what-project-of-yours-are-you/714u

https://github.com/GingkathFox?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language=

https://github.com/Foxite?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language= and https://gitlab.com/users/foxite/projects

https://github.com/jakemayeux?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language=

https://github.com/Dog2puppy?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language=

body:
Proficient in PHP? No. If you look at the one project I have in PHP, you'll see that I worked on it for exactly one day and then quit. The two recent JS projects I have are very small. One of them was a school project, which provides a lot of incentive, leading to accelerated progress, as headzoo described.

You don't want me to feel obligated to help you which I don't. But I don't want you to feel like you're shit, which you're not.

Proficient in PHP? No. If you look at the one project I have in PHP, you'll see that I worked on it for exactly one day and then quit. The two recent JS projects I have are very small. You don't want me to feel obligated to help you which I don't. But I don't want you to feel like you're shit, which you're not.

parent.body:
You're proficient in PHP and python too, and even JS as much as it sucks. It seems you can learn a language very quickly. You wrote a fully functional forum in PHP in about a week's time. It'd take me months to do that, even if that was my main language. I also can't ever polish anything to be even remotely releasable, which all of you do frequently in hours/days time (if it's small). This includes higher level stuff.

GingkathFox wrote a browser and several large libraries with actual releases. I wouldn't call that simple.

I don't want you to feel obligated to help me here. I think I've bothered you enough with this already before, and I don't want to pester you again. It's not your problem, it's mine, and you can't waste all your time dealing with me.

This includes higher level stuff.

GingkathFox wrote a browser and several large libraries with actual releases. I wouldn't call that simple.

I don't want you to feel obligated to help me here. I think I've bothered you enough with this already before, and I don't want to pester you again. It's not your problem, it's mine, and you can't waste all your time dealing with me.

post.body:
It is pretty pointless to have a "private profile" if someone can just search for your username on Google with site:ruqqus.com and find all your posts / comments. In fact it is a bit problematic to give people a false sense of security by providing this feature but having it not really protect them.

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?
post.body_html:
It is pretty pointless to have a "private profile" if someone can just search for your username on Google with site:ruqqus.com and find all your posts / comments. In fact it is a bit problematic to give people a false sense of security by providing this feature but having it not really protect them.

Is there a way you can remove people's username from the comments section on the version of the website that is served to search engines? Or maybe just don't show the username at all when they have a private profile. There isn't really any reason we need to see usernames, right?
post.title: Serious Problem with Private Profiles

body:
/r/redpandas has huge stickied wall of text on every single post that goes into great detail about how they are endangered and what you can do to help. The exact same information is available on the subreddit sticky post, which likewise is only going to be read by people who would actually donate in the first place.

It's completely useless.

It's completely useless.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

For press releases, visit +RuqqusPress.

For updates and patch notes, visit +changelog.

For ideas and feedback, visit +BetaFeedback

For bug reports, visit +RuqqusBugs

post.body:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship. 

What is Ruqqus going to do about that?  Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
post.body_html:
We all know that Reddit has an automoderator bot. While it is useful for most cases, sometimes mods abuse it to censorship.

What is Ruqqus going to do about that? Will we have a bot that can't be abused by mods or it won't come at all?
post.title: Ruqqus' stance on automoderator bots

post.body:
RIP Linus (20+ something years old, unsure when born), The furriest of bois.

Literally. Still finding deposits of fur around the house.

It was a sad day when he had to be put to sleep due to failing health. He was a very loving cat despite him acting haughty and aloof of your presence, but for receiving attention and food.

post.title: RIP Linus (199x - Feb 2020)

body:
I've noticed this as well. I noticed that just a picture of a fox does not get much attention; only if the picture is outstanding or uncommon in some way it will receive significant upvotes. So a fox stealing a carrot from a snowman will receive more rep than a generic image of a fox that's just walking. A picture of a grey fox sleeping on someone's car is more upvote-worthy than a fox sleeping in a forest somewhere, because it isn't common.

That's the main reason, but another important factor is probably just luck.
body_html:

A picture of a grey fox sleeping on someone's car is more upvote-worthy than a fox sleeping in a forest somewhere, because it isn't common.

That's the main reason, but another important factor is probably just luck.
